awd_titl_txt: Travel: Student Travel Support to NAS 2021
awd_abstract_narration:
This request is for support to broaden and diversify the student participation in the 15th IEEE International Conference on Networking, Architecture, and Storage (NAS), a premier international forum for the presentation of research results in networking, high-performance computer architecture, and parallel and distributed data storage technologies. It seeks to increase student participation in the conference and the field. The proposed funding would support the travel of eligible US students to the conference. Travel grants encourage the research interests and the involvement of students in the field who are not well funded and those who are just beginning their participation in the field or are interested in entering it. A special effort is made to reach out to women and under-represented minorities. Preference is given to students who will present their research at NAS.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project was to support students from US universities to attend the 15th IEEE International Conference on Networking, Architecture, and Storage (NAS 2021), held from October 24-26, 2021 at Riverside Conference Center, USA. NAS 2021 provided a high-quality international forum to bring together researchers and practitioners from academia and industry to discuss innovative research on networking, high-performance computer architecture, and data storage technologies. The conference was sponsored by the IEEE Computer Society Technical Committee on Distributed Processing (TCDP). NAS 2021 program committee was chaired by well-known researchers in the areas of networking, architecture, and storage. Exposing and encouraging student participation (especially women and underrepresented minority groups) in NAS-focused areas is critical to exposing the next generation of researchers to the current state-of-the-art technologies and carry forward research in these areas.

A member of the NAS 21 organizing committee managed the NSF travel grant. A call for applications for travel support was posted at the NAS 2021 website. The project personnel reviewed the qualifications of applicants and finally awarded 29 travel grants to students to attend the conference. Priority was given to student authors and minority participation. The NSF funding enabled students' travel from many US universities and successfully increased the students' participation of this conference. Through attending the conference, these students increased their knowledge on the state-of-the-art technologies on networking, architecture, and storage. This NSF project contributed to increasing the size and diversity of the U.S. science and technology workforce by providing an opportunity for graduate students to supplement their training, build networks, and explore career options. Several women and minority students received the NSF travel grant and attended the conference.

 


Last Modified: 09/28/2022
Modified by: Laxmi N Bhuyan
